Description: Body sherd, possibly part of the conical foot, of Chian pottery chalice; white slip; exterior reserved; inscription on exterior.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Great Temenos, Vicinity (outside) of the north-west corner (Hogarth excavations 1903) (probably)
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The sherd is unusual as the conical foot on chalices is typically slipped white and then glazed black over top. Hogarth mentioned that this sherd was likely discovered among a large amount of Egyptian finds in a trench he made to the North-West of the Great Temenos (Masson forthcoming). Masson, A. forthcoming, ‘Egyptian Naukratis: the early evidence’, in A. Wodzińska (ed.), Delta and Sinai Current research, Proceedings of the conference in the University of Warsaw, Warsaw, April 25-27 2013.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.1236) (phase 2)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
